drawing_instructions.thinking: Looking at the blank canvas, I want to express sadness through rain drops falling from dark clouds. I'll start with a gloomy cloud shape in the upper portion using the wiggle brush in a dark sky blue color. The wavy strokes will create a melancholic mood that reflects my sad feelings. The scattered, drooping cloud formation will hover heavily in the sky, symbolizing the weight of sadness.

I see the gloomy clouds at the top of the canvas. To enhance the feeling of sadness, I'll now add falling raindrops using the spray brush. The scattered dots will create a rain effect, falling vertically from the clouds. I'll concentrate the rain drops more heavily in some areas to create a sense of heavy downpour, which reflects the intensity of the sad emotions. The rain will start just below the wiggly clouds and extend downward.

Looking at the rainy scene, I want to add teardrops to represent deep sadness. I'll use the crayon brush with a light blue color to draw three large teardrop shapes below the rain. The tears will be heavier and more defined than the rain drops above, symbolizing personal sorrow mixing with the rain. I'll place them in the lower portion of the canvas, as if they're falling from the rain clouds but more substantial and emotional.

Looking at the rainy scene with clouds, rain, and teardrops, I want to add some darker, heavier clouds using the marker brush to intensify the gloomy atmosphere. I'll use a dark sky blue shade (#1B5C72) to create dense, heavy clouds that seem to be pressing down with the weight of sadness. I'll place these above the existing wiggly clouds to add depth and emotional heaviness to the scene.

Looking at the melancholic rainy scene, I want to add some lighter, translucent layers to the clouds to create a sense of depth and heaviness. I'll use the marker brush with a lighter sky blue color (#99D3E7) to add overlapping oval shapes above the existing dark clouds. This will create a misty, foggy effect that enhances the gloomy atmosphere and represents the clouding of thoughts when feeling sad. The overlapping shapes will be placed strategically to create a sense of depth and emotional weight.

Looking at the somber rainy scene, I want to add some wavy, flowing lines using the wiggle brush to represent streams of tears or sorrowful waves beneath the clouds. These will be placed between the clouds and rain, using a deep sky blue (#1B5C72) to create a sense of flowing emotion and continuous sadness. The wavy lines will connect the cloud formations and add a sense of movement and melancholy to the composition.

Looking at the rainy, melancholic scene, I want to add more teardrops falling from the clouds using the spray brush. The scattered dots will create a sense of heavy rainfall that blends with tears, representing overwhelming sadness. I'll focus on creating three distinct streams of rain/tears falling from each cloud formation, with the dots becoming denser as they fall, symbolizing how sadness can become heavier and more intense as it builds up. This will enhance the emotional weight of the scene.

Looking at this melancholic scene, I want to add some falling teardrop shapes using the marker brush. These teardrops will be larger and more defined than the spray rain, using a light sky blue (#99D3E7) to create a sense of gentle, quiet sadness. I'll place them at the bottom of each rain stream, as if they're the culmination of all the smaller raindrops - like how small sorrows can collect into bigger feelings. They'll be slightly translucent to blend with the existing elements.

Looking at this rainy scene of sorrow, I want to add more wavy lines using the wiggle brush to create a sense of emotional turbulence and unrest. I'll place them beneath the existing wavy lines, making them more chaotic and irregular to represent inner emotional turmoil. Using a darker shade of sky blue (#1B5C72) will emphasize the depth of sadness. These new waves will be slightly more compressed and irregular than the ones above, suggesting mounting pressure and distress.

Looking at the rain-filled scene, I want to add one more set of wavy lines using the wiggle brush near the bottom of the clouds. These will be more subdued and drooping, like the heaviness of sadness weighing down. I'll use the darkest sky blue (#0D2E39) to represent the deepest layer of melancholy, placing them where the clouds' influence begins to merge with the falling rain. The waves will be slightly more compressed than the previous ones, suggesting a feeling of being overwhelmed.

Looking at the rainy scene with its layers of sorrow, I want to add another set of wavering lines to represent the most turbulent feelings of sadness. I'll place these waves at a crucial transition point using the wiggle brush, making them more erratic and closer together than the previous waves. Using the darkest sky blue (#0D2E39) will help convey the depths of despair. These lines will be positioned near where the rain begins to intensify, symbolizing how emotions can spiral and become more chaotic as they build.

Looking at the stormy, emotional scene, I want to add some heavier cloud formations at the top using the marker brush. These will be overlapping, swollen clouds in a deep sky blue (#1B5C72) to emphasize the weight of sadness pressing down from above. I'll create several overlapping oval shapes that merge together, like heavy thoughts that crowd the mind when feeling down. The clouds will be placed near the top of the canvas, their dense appearance suggesting the overwhelming nature of melancholy.

Looking at this deeply melancholic scene, I want to add more teardrops merging with the rain using the wiggle brush. I'll create gently curved, downward-flowing lines that start thin and widen as they fall, like tears gaining momentum. Using a lighter shade of Sky Blue (#99D3E7) will create a sense of fragility and vulnerability. I'll position these between the existing rain streams, making them wavy and uncertain, reflecting how emotions can feel unstable when we're sad. The lines will curve and weave, suggesting the way tears can trace unpredictable paths as they fall.

Looking at this sorrowful rainy scene, I want to add some gentle, teardrop-shaped puddles at the bottom using the marker brush. These will be in a light sky blue (#99D3E7) to represent the collection of tears and rain at the base. I'll create three soft, irregular pools that spread out gently, like how sadness can pool and spread in our hearts. They'll be placed beneath the main rain streams, creating a sense of accumulated melancholy.

Looking at this rainy scene of sorrow, I want to add more intensity to the rainfall using the spray brush. The scattered dots will create a dense curtain of rain, representing the overwhelming feeling of sadness that surrounds us. I'll concentrate the spray in vertical columns between the existing wiggly lines, making it heavier in the middle section where emotions feel most intense. This will add depth and a sense of isolation to the scene, as if viewing the world through a veil of tears.
